questions.text: Which of the following is a class IC anti-arrhythmic drug, per Vaughan-Williams classification?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Propafenone Anti-arrhythmic drugs, as per Vaughan-Williams classification

Highyeild:

Propafenone (Class IC) Used to treat symptomatic supraventricular arrhythmias and suppress life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias. It is structurally similar to propranolol and has beta- blocking activity in addition to its sodium channel blocking activity. At therapeutic concentrations it can have significant beta-blocking activity which must be considered in patients with heart failure.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lignocaine

Highyeild:

Digitalis-induced ventricular arrhythmias: Lidocaine or phenytoin, which have minimal effects on AV conduction, may be used to treat ventricular arrhythmias that threaten hemodynamic compromise. Electrical cardioversion increases the risk of inducing severe rhythm disturbances in patients with overt digitalis toxicity and should be used cautiously. Inhibition of the Na+, K+-ATPase activity of skeletal muscle can cause hyperkalemia. An effective antidote for life-threatening digoxin (or digitoxin) toxicity is DIGIBIND.

questions.text: Among the following options, which one is the DOC for ventricular fibrillation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amiodarone DOC for ventricular fibrillation/tachycardia is Amiodarone

Highyeild:

Amiodarone is effective in a wide range of ventricular and supraventricular arrhythmias, including PSVT, nodal and ventricular tachycardia, AF, AFL, etc. Resistant VT and recurrent VF are the most important indications. It also maintains sinus rhythm in AF when other drugs have failed. Rapid termination of ventricular (VT and VF) and supraventricular arrhythmias can be obtained by i.v. Injection. WPW tachyarrhythmia is terminated by suppression of both normal and aberrant pathways. The long duration of action makes amiodarone suitable for chronic prophylactic therapy. Apart from propranolol, it is the only antiarrhythmic drug that, in the long term, has been found to reduce sudden cardiac death. Because of high and broad-spectrum efficacy and relatively low proarrhythmic potential, amiodarone is a very commonly used antiarrhythmic, despite its organ toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in atrial arrhythmias?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mexiletine

Highyeild:

It is an analogue of lidocaine It has been modified to reduce first-pass hepatic metabolism and permit chronic oral therapy Mechanism of action similar to Lignocaine It is approved for treating ventricular arrhythmias Lidocaine: It is relatively selective for partially depolarized cells and those with longer APD (whose Na+ Channels remain inactivated for longer periods). While normal ventricular and conducting fibers are minimally affected, depolarized/damaged fibers are significantly depressed. The brevity of atrial AP and lack of lidocaine effect on channel recovery might explain its inefficacy in atrial arrhythmias.
